A heating pad or ice pack can provide temporary relief for back pain, but they won't address the underlying issues that cause the pain. 

Strengthening exercises like the ones I mentioned earlier can help improve muscle strength, flexibility, and balance, which can help prevent future lower back pain. These exercises can also improve posture and reduce the risk of injury.

In addition to strengthening exercises, stretching, and other forms of exercise can also help reduce back pain. Walking, swimming, and yoga are all low-impact activities that can help improve flexibility and strengthen the muscles that support your lower back.

It's important to remember that taking care of your back is an ongoing process. By making small changes in your daily routine, such as taking breaks from sitting, doing exercises regularly, and maintaining good posture, you can help prevent lower back pain from becoming a chronic problem. Nonetheless, if you continue to experience persistent or severe pain, it's important to seek advice from a medical professional.
